overall_summary: The reasoning demonstrates a practical approach to time-series forecasting under data constraints, focusing on daily seasonality identification. It evaluates multiple methods but settles on simple averaging due to limited historical data (only 4 days), acknowledging trade-offs between complexity and feasibility while ensuring robustness for potential missing values.
common_data_patterns: Variation by day of week (weekdays vs. weekends)
No missing values in provided data
Characteristic load patterns (night lows, morning/evening peaks)
key_insights: Daily seasonality is the primary identifiable pattern given limited data
Insufficient historical data prevents modeling weekly seasonality or trends
Hourly averaging provides a robust solution when same-day-of-week data is unavailable
Method prioritizes simplicity and missing-value robustness over complexity
Explicit handling of day-of-week mismatches between historical and forecast periods
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex: Evaluates advanced methods (e.g., ETS, ARIMA) but intentionally simplifies to averaging due to data limitations, with detailed hourly-level computations and day-of-week considerations.
